thread.title: CME Fined Trader $55,000 for ‘Spoofing’ Treasury Futures in 2011
thread.title_full: CME Fined Trader $55,000 for ‘Spoofing’ Treasury Futures in 2011 - Bloomberg Business

author: Brian Louis
title: CME Fined Trader $55,000 for ‘Spoofing’ Treasury Futures in 2011
text:
CME Group Inc. fined a trader, James Groth, $55,000 and suspended him for 10 days for engaging in a banned practice known as spoofing on the futures exchange.
From May 2011 through October 2011, Groth on several occasions submitted orders for Treasury futures without intending to actually complete those transactions, according to Chicago-based CME. Spoofing is against exchange rules because it’s a form of market manipulation that can trick other traders into thinking prices are poised to move.
Groth neither admitted nor denied the allegations, according to CME’s statement on its investigation. CME runs the Chicago Board of Trade, an exchange where futures on U.S. Treasuries are bought and sold.
He didn’t respond to an e-mail or voicemail message.
